newsitem.title: JAPAN: No concern about car output after Toyota fire - EPA.
newsitem.headline: No concern about car output after Toyota fire - EPA.

text.p: Economic Planning Agency (EPA) Minister Taro Aso said on Friday he is not worried about the effects of the fire at a Toyota Motor Corp parts supplier's factory on Japan's overall production of cars.
"At the moment, it appears that the fire is not having much effect on overall car production and private consumption. So there is no cause for worry," Aso told a news conference.

The fire on Saturday at a plant of Aisin Seiki Co Ltd prevented output of brake parts supplied to Toyota, forcing the idling of all the carmaker's domestic plants on Tuesday, except for those of Daihatsu Motor Co Ltd.
Toyota said on Friday that production has resumed at all its domestic plants.
Earlier on Friday, an Economic Planning Agency (EPA) official said industrial production in Japan in February is likely to be affected by the fire.

The official, commenting on the agency's monthly economic report, said while it was difficult to judge the extent of the impact, it was unlikely to be dramatic enough to change the overall rising trend of industrial output.

Car production represented 7.2 percent of output in the October-December period, of which Toyota's output was about one-third -- which would lop 0.1 percent off industrial output for every day Toyota's production lines were idle, he said.
